utterances.sentences: Wow, he says here now exclusively, President Trump's attorney Rudy Giuliani. Would you like a chance to cross-examine him, sir? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb14', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb14', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: RUDY GIULIANI, LAWYER OF PRESIDENT TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Oh gosh, yes, my goodness. I mean, he doesn't realize that the dictionary definition of surveillance is spying or vice versa. I mean, does he know that there was certain things called synonyms. But in any event, you know, Jim, unfortunately, has disgraced himself as head of the FBI, a ridiculous way he conducted the Hillary Clinton investigation.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: So what is he hiding?

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: He's hiding the fact that he probably perjured himself with regard to the FISA applications. He's certainly engaged in a word -- he loves gross negligence. He presented an application to the FISA Court where he has a special obligation to tell the other side of the story because it's never told, and I helped create the FISA Court so I think I'd probably understand it may be a little better than he does and I sure understand the obligations you have better than he does.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: So what is your reaction --

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: So he presented the steel dossier as if it was a piece of intelligence. It wasn't a piece of intelligence, Ed, it was a piece of garbage. I've read intelligence document. He'd go through the first three pages, this is something that should be you know, read in a -- in some dirty club or something, and it's really ridiculous. And then he never did anything to corroborate it. He said it's unverified. He's the director of the FBI. He's supposed to verify it, Jim you got to verify it. Here what you could -- here's what you could verify. You could have asked Steele, when is the last time you're in Russia. He'd have told you nine years ago. Or you could have looked at his passport document.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Sure. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: That might have raised a question about whether it was phony or not. Or there's a specific allegation that Michael Cohen was in Prague on a particular date. I can't imagine FBI agents on their own not checking out with the passport office. Let's see if we can verify this little piece of information with this highly questionable document.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: So Mr. Mayor, this has not been investigated thoroughly. Now, William Barr is saying it was spying. How significant is that? Eric Trump was on "FOX & FRIENDS" this morning saying now there's an adult in the room and they're going to get to the bottom of it.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Thank God. I mean, it's been a long time that we've had equal justice. I mean, the revelations of crimes committed by the people who instigated this investigation and some of the things they've done along the way are actually much more concerning than the ridiculous allegation of collusion which has no substance. Crimes were committed by the people who instigated this investigation. It starts with the four applications to the FISA Court which are fraudulent, they're phony, they're false.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Let me ask you whether you're concerned though, you're in Washington conducting this interview and we appreciate it because you're waiting for the redacted version of the Mueller report. Are you nervous? Are you going to have a rebuttal ready if there's information that suggests that they came close to obstruction? What do you -- are you nervous about it?

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: I've been waiting -- I've been waiting for the -- for the time to do that you know, for almost a year now. So yes, we're ready and we'll be ready for anything they throw at us. I suspect it'll be nothing that we're not prepared for or haven't thought of, the president hasn't thought of, and we were ready for it three months ago. And the reality is there was no collusion. It's a joke but it's worse than a joke. It was a setup. It was a specific conspiracy to frame him. I think the facts are starting to come in on that. Pay attention to Ukraine, something the -- what do we call it, the mainstream media won't cover the scandal going on there, the investigation by the Ukrainian government of Ukrainians who possibly conspired with a Hilton -- the Clinton campaign and the DNC -- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Right, those allegations are out there but --

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: -- to create the Manafort dossier or Manafort black book. And possibly, if Comey had looked and realized that Steele wasn't in Russia for nine years, he might have asked well, where did this come from. I think there might be an answer to that in a week or two.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Mr. Mayor, I got two other quick questions. One, but did the President and others spike the football too soon since you didn't see the full report yet? Are you concerned that there -- you say no collusion, I got it, but on obstruction are you concerned at all?

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Obstruction, I'm ready to debate obstruction you know, for 50 hours anybody who wants to debate it. Obstruction is a created fiction. The President of the United States did not obstruct. How can you obstruct when there's no underlying crime? Everything they're talking about that he did, this is an innocent man defending himself. If I'm accused of robbing a bank and I didn't do it, and I was with my friend the night that it happened, and I tweet out and I write to my friend and I say please tell them the truth, and if you don't you're a rat because you're lying. That's an innocent man defending himself. That is not so a corrupt intent.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: So last question Mr. Mayor.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: That is not obstruction. What they are trying to take away from us, Weissman and Mueller's gang, these deranged Democrats is our ability to defend ourselves, and damn it, I'm not let them do that. We're going to defend ourselves. The president is innocent. He's innocent of collusion. They are guilty of trying to frame him and he's completely innocent of obstruction. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Mr. Mayor, I've got very short time. What do you think about Congresswoman Omar and what she said about 9/11?

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: She's a disgrace. I mean, how can I not feel that way? I've lived through it. I lost good friends and as I wrote last night, I've watched the children grow up without mothers and fathers. And something, Congresswoman, did happen. Don't demean it. Don't hurt these people. I don't know what your politics are. I'm really confused by it. I don't know what your sense of America is. I hope it's there, but I'm sure it is, but you did something wrong and I'd like to see you apologize for it and maybe we get we got a straight path then. And I'd like to see some of the Democrats have the courage to speak out against her. I'm getting the feeling that they live under censorship of you know, left-wing propaganda.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Well, when she made the comments that were seen as anti-Semitic, they had a resolution but they didn't even named her, Mr. Mayor so they haven't taken --

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Oh, that was garbage, that resolution. I mean, that was so cowardly -- they should be hiding somewhere.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Mayor Rudy Giuliani, we appreciate you coming in.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Thank you. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: We'll be watching and waiting as you are this weekend. Thank you, sir. More on Congresswoman Omar next.

utterances.speaker: REP. ILHAN OMAR, D-MINN
utterances.sentences: Here was founded after 9/11 because they recognized that some people did something and that all of us were starting to lose access to our civil liberties.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Well, those newly revealed comments that "some people did something on 9/11 by Democratic Congresswoman Ilhan Omar at an event for the Council on American-Islamic Relations last month prompted some swift and intense backlash. But the freshman fighting back tonight, even invoking the words of President George HW Bush in her defense. Tweeting, the people and the people who knocked these buildings down will hear all of us soon. Was bush she wrote, downplaying the terrorist attack? What if he was a Muslim? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } President Trump a short time ago fired back with a tweet of his own saying, simply we will never forget. Earlier I spoke to Hassan Shibly, Head of CAIR's Florida Chapter. He was actually there with the Congresswoman at the event when she made those remarks about 9/11. Here he is.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Why couldn't she say instead of some people did something, how about saying some savage terrorists killed 3,000 Americans?

utterances.speaker: HASSAN SHIBLY, CHIEF EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, CAIR FLORIDA
utterances.sentences: Well, because it goes without saying that whoever did the horrific acts of 9/11 are savage, terrorist, monsters. And the presumption that a Muslim congresswoman especially or any Muslim would think otherwise is itself an Islamophobic trope. She should be afforded the same deference that the average white American --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: So why didn't she show basic respect for the dead?

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: Like you just said, President Bush --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Pardon me, sir, but why didn't -- you say it goes without saying. Why not say it and then go on with whatever your point is and say savage terrorist, radical Islamic terrorists killed innocent Americans? Why not say that? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: I encourage everybody to watch the full 20 minutes to get the full context. The video was actually viewed over two million times because Fox News itself live-streamed it, and for three weeks nobody made an issue of this because if you watch the full twenty minutes, it was appropriate. The point she was trying to make was that literally some people did something and it was horrible and as a result of some people doing something literally there has been countless hate crimes against community. Millions of American Muslims have been treated like second-class citizens and just a week before, let's not forget that these comments came a week after 50 Muslims were killed in cold blood in New Zealand.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: And that was disgusting.

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: So the point of the message was that a lot of people lost the rights -- a lot of the people lost the rights because of the horrific acts of a few monsters.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: OK. And you know what, if I was talking about -- if I decided to give a speech about the Muslims who were savagely killed unfairly, tragically in New Zealand, I wouldn't say some people -- something happened to some people. I would say that 50 Muslims were savagely killed and then I would move on with what I had to say. Why couldn't she just say it for what it was?

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: I mean, she has many, many times. And it's I think --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Where she said it? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: She's held to a double -- she's held -- let me be clear, she's held to a double standard. In fact, many times white American men have said the exact kinds of things the Congresswomen Ihan Omar have said but they have not faced the backlash because there is a hypocrisy. And I want to say, where is the condemnation for the death threats that in had almost continuously received?

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Well, she should not get the death threats.

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: Where are the condemnations for the loyalty to being questioned? She continuously --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: OK, no one is calling for here to be killed. That is outrageous. She should not face death threats. But --

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: And that's happening daily. Every single day she's getting all these death threats --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Here's my last question, sir. To be clear, she should never face a death threat. No Democrat, Republican, man, woman, Catholic, Muslim, it's outrageous what's happening in terms of the political dialogue and she should not face these death threats. But here's my question. Does she not have some responsibility herself with her own words? Let's not forget she recently made these controversial comments about in America and around the world Jews, in America and around the world. Shouldn't she be a little more careful with her own tone?

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: I think she's being held to a completely unfair standard. President Trump himself has made anti-Semitic remarks questioning the loyalty of Jews, calling the prime minister of Israel the leader of American Jews. He didn't get any backlash, he --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: That wasn't anti-Semitic. President Trump was not being anti- Semitic in praising the Israeli --

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: He was being anti-Semitic. That was an anti-Semitic trope. No one. He was claiming American Jews' leader was Netanyahu.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: OK. But that wasn't my question. My question is --

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: Again, there's a difference --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: -- I've got 15 seconds. I'm going to give you a chance. You can say no.

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: But should she be responsible for her words?

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: I think people need to hear her words in the full context and I believe if everybody goes to the Fox News web site, watch as the full 20 minutes of her lecture, they won't have objections to what she said.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: And my producers are telling me in my ear that that is on the web site.

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: Let us start talking and even if we disagree with each other --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: And they should hear her.

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: -- let us not fight.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: Yes, it is. It is. And let us just, even if we disagree with each other let's not incite hatred against each other. The New York Post went too far by using horrific image of 9/11 to incite hate against her. We can disagree without hating each other, without having death threats --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Got it.

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: -- and I appreciate you condemning the death threats that she's been receiving.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: No. It should be condemned. And nobody wants to incite hate. I agree with you with 100 percent on that. Thank you, sir. I appreciate you coming in.

utterances.speaker: SHIBLY
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Well, here to respond, former navy SEAL, Rob O'Neill, the man, of course, who killed Osama bin Laden. Never quite answer the question about her at all.

utterances.speaker: ROB O'NEILL, RETIRED NAVY SEAL
utterances.sentences: No, he didn't answer the question. I want to -- thanks for having me, first of all.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: I kind of what to caveat this with I don't know if the congresswoman -- she grew up born -- she was born in Somalia. You know, I was born in Montana, I've never walked in her shoes. I love diversity. I fought alongside Muslims. It was never about against Islam. It was about an ideology. We fought with Muslims, we fought pretty much everywhere. But something as simple as saying some people did some stuff -- maybe it was in the moment, maybe it's out of context, but if someone points out hey, that's really offensive because of the horrific day, there's nothing wrong with saying, you know it? I'm sorry. I didn't mean to --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: I should've condemned it.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: I should have condemned. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: The rest of my speech stands.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: She does know what she's doing and she likes those tweets. I mean, a few weeks after Benghazi, she tweeted "Allahu akbar," God is great. And according to her faith, yes, God is great but it's kind of one of those jabs, like you don't really need to say that. And then the other thing that kind of bothers me is that on the left, they don't really condemn it. And they come out and start calling people Islamophobic and racist and they say that she's being attacked by the New York Post because they don't like women of color. And that's an insult I'm assuming to the women of color, the people of color who died in the towers, who jump out of windows on the --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Muslims who died in the towers.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: Muslims that died in the towers. And it's not as simple as some people who did some stuff. Think about the people that when they jump, yes, they died on impact, but they had that entire fall to think about things that really mattered. And it's more than people did some stuff. And again, like I said, when we were fighting, with my friends and I that work -- we weren't fighting for America against Islam, we were fighting for the western world against an ideology. I'm a public speaker. I remember one of the best compliments I got a few months ago, a man came up to me and said that I'm a Muslim-American and today I was very proud of you. And that stuck with me because it's not us against them and this division.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: They're trying to put in there because they got a few sound bites.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: I've got 15 seconds.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: I was at the Tunnel to Towers Foundation fundraiser last night. It honors Stephen Siller, a firefighter here in New York City who tragically died in 9/11.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: That's on -- yes.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: You're aware of it. My question, my point is he ran into those buildings to try to save people and he didn't know whether they were men, women, Muslims, Catholics, he just wanted to save people.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes. And just thinking about that, those people were coming out of the tower to live, those firefighters were going up to die, and that's what the day is all about. And that should bring us together. It shouldn't be stupid politics. If you screw up -- and I believe I've screwed up.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: I've said the wrong things. And you know, if I offended you up -- I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Rob O'Neill, we appreciate your services.

utterances.speaker: O'NEILL
utterances.sentences: Thanks. Of course. My honor. It's an honor.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: All right. More on “The Story,” next.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Well, it's a hot topic already on the 2020 campaign trail. And now Georgetown University just took the first of its kind a step to address the issue of reparations. Students there voting overwhelmingly, a margin of 66 percent to 33 percent, to approve a fee of $27 per student to help fund charitable causes that directly benefit descendants of slaves once sold by the Jesuits in 1838. Now the measure still requires final approval from the university's board. So, what do you think about this? Lawrence Jones, editor of chief at Campus Reform and Fox News contributor. Jason Nichols is an American studies professor at a nearby college, University of Maryland, I should say, at College Park. Gentlemen, good to see you.

utterances.speaker: JASON NICHOLS, PROFESSOR, UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND
utterances.sentences: Good to see you, Ed.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Lawrence, what do you think about this?

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE JONES, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Well, like I tell people all the time, all the stories that we report on Campus Reform, the colleges are setting the tone for the culture. Remember, the majority of the presidential candidates are on the Democratic field, on the Democratic side, agree with proposals like this. The problem is how do you determine who are the descendants of slaves and how is this actually going to help black folks in the long run? I tend to subscribe to the T.I. format and the Nipsey (Ph) format where the community members that have made it go back and reinvest back into the community so we can be successful. I don't see how this helps anyway.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Jason, how do you respond?

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Well, again, I think one of the things nationwide we have to do is study it and that's pretty much all of what the candidates have said. They haven't committed themselves to anything. In this particular case with Georgetown University, the university community came together and said, this is something we wanted to do and we are willing to fund it. And $27 a semester is a dinner at the Olive Garden. And this is one of the wealthiest universities, has one of the wealthiest populations of any of the universities in the country. To me, it sounds like they've made a resounding decision and we should respect what it is they've done at their university.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: But Jason, you said --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes, but --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Go ahead, go ahead, Lawrence. Jump in.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Yes. But how does it actually solve the issue? And the question is who benefits from it?

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: Are we going to have a bunch of Elizabeth Warren's who are running around claiming that they were descendants of slaves as well --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes, answer that, Jason.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: In this particular case --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: -- and would dictate who were -- who are part.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: OK. In this particular case, they know that the descendants of the 272 slave -- enslaved people, so there -- it is the actual --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: You're talking about from the --

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: No, it's not about DNA, it's about record-keeping. The Jesuits kept records of who they enslaved. And then you have, you know, these archives, I don't know if you've watched an episode of "Finding Your Roots," but there is a such thing as archives where people can find out who their ancestors were and who they were enslaved by. So, in this particular case, I agree that it's going to be much more difficult when we talk about it nationwide. But in this particular case, you have the actual descendants of the enslaved people, and the university decided --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: -- that they wanted to do this.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: So, perhaps a narrow case, as you say, at Georgetown. Lawrence, how do you do this nationwide?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.sentences: You can't do it nationwide. I have a big problem with people paying for the citizens of their ancestors. Look, I'm a firm believer that black folks don't need any help from white individuals out there that struggle with some type of guilt. Just give us equality and let us move on. There's a lot of people in our community that are willing to build up our community and we can do it by ourselves. We don't need any other people contributing because they feel some type of guilt for what their ancestors did.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: All right. Lawrence, Jason, I appreciate you both coming in.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Thanks a lot, Ed. Thanks, Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: All right. Up next, progressive groups launch a new assault on Justice Kavanaugh, demanding Congress now investigate what they call a sham confirmation.

utterances.speaker: BRETT KAVANAUGH, ASSOCIATE JUSTICE, SUPREME COURT
utterances.sentences: I know my lifelong record and I'm not going to let false accusations drive me out of this process.

utterances.speaker: SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM, R-S.C.
utterances.sentences: This is the most unethical sham since I've been in politics.

utterances.speaker: KAVANAUGH
utterances.sentences: I've never sexually assaulted anyone. Not in the high school, not in college, not ever.

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: You are looking for a fair process? You came to the wrong town at the wrong time.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Remember that? Well, Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh are now facing new attacks on multiple fronts tonight. First, more than 2,000 progressive groups have now sent a letter to Congress demanding that they investigate Kavanaugh's, quote, "sham confirmation process." One group is called "demand justice." Their executive director, Brian Fallon, happens to be Hillary Clinton's former campaign spokesman. His group is also backing a separate campaign, to get Kavanaugh fired from a guest professor position with George Mason University. Writing, quote, "Kavanaugh has been credibly accused, they claim, of sexual assault by multiple women whose allegations have not been thoroughly investigated," they also claim. "His confirmation does not absolve him of guilt," they write, "and he should not be given a platform to teach." Here now, Ben Domenech, he's publisher of course, of the Federalist, Jehmu Greene, and former candidate for DNC chair, and a Fox News contributor. Good to see you both.

utterances.speaker: BEN DOMENECH, PUBLISHER, THE FEDERALIST
utterances.sentences: Good to be with you.

utterances.speaker: JEHMU GREENE, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Good evening, Ed.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Jehmu, this just seems to be the height of resist.

utterances.speaker: GREENE
utterances.sentences: Well, I certainly hope that we can all agree that no American is above the law, whether you are a president of the United States or a Supreme Court justice.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: So, what law did he break, Jehmu?

utterances.speaker: GREENE
utterances.sentences: Well, I think what these organizations are asking for is an investigation that will end up with more transparency and accountability than we've seen in this process up until now. Look, I do not think this is the number one priority for progressive organizations as we head into 2020, but I do think that if this boils down to transparency and accountability and how we can make sure that we have adequate investigations for the leaders of the land --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GREENE
utterances.sentences: -- and it doesn't happen again. I think that's a good thing.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Ben, I thought the FBI took of look at this.

utterances.speaker: DOMENECH
utterances.sentences: You know, they did take a look at this. But, you know, you play that bit of hellish rebuke from Senator Graham and Justice Kavanaugh himself in response to these allegations, what you didn't play is the video of those angry leftist protesters who went over across the street and bang their hands on the doors of the Supreme Court in one of the most ineffectual and overwrought displays I've ever seen in reaction to the Supreme Court nomination. And that's what these investigations really are. They're simply an attack on Kavanaugh's reputation, they are designed to continue to smear him. And what we know from our own reporting, my colleague Mollie Hemingway who overheard, you know, now House judiciary chairman Jerry Nadler discussing this issue on the phone on the Amtrak train --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DOMENECH
utterances.sentences: -- immediately following election day in which he said openly that he wanted to try to spin up investigation to find a way to impeach Justice Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: DOMENECH
utterances.sentences: That's how toxic these debates are.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: So, I also mentioned George Mason University. Here's what some students they are saying that I'll give everybody a chance to respond. Listen.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I'm a survivor of sexual assault. This decision has really impacted me negatively and it has affected my mental health knowing that an abuser will be a part of our faculty.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I do not feel confident with someone who has sexual assault allegations like walking our campus.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The hiring of Kavanaugh threatens the mental wellbeing of all survivors on this campus.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Jehmu, I know it's hard to hear because they are talking in a forum. But one said I'm not comparable with someone who has sexual assault allegations.

utterances.speaker: GREENE
utterances.sentences: She did. And it was a little bit hard to hear but I could also hear the pain in her voice, Ed. And you know, as we look at the way that there is no process in which for any investigation to be had within our judicial branch, it is absolutely important that these voices are heard, that there is a forum --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GREENE
utterances.sentences: -- for people to be able to express this. And we can I hope agree that our Democratic norms have been tested, broken, thrown out the window - -

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: OK. Let's --

utterances.speaker: GREENE
utterances.sentences: -- in the last three years by this administration.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Let's let Ben respond.

utterances.speaker: GREENE
utterances.sentences: And we need to get back to a sense of normalcy. I think an investigation like this will help us do that.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Al right. Ben, quick respond.

utterances.speaker: DOMENECH
utterances.sentences: There is no norm that's been thrown out more significantly than the treatment of the judicial nomination process in the United States Senate, something that Democrats themselves broke and that it ended catching them in a bad situation with this nomination in a way that many people predicted would come back to bite Harry Reid at the time.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: And here we are. Ben, last --

utterances.speaker: GREENE
utterances.sentences: Republics stole a Supreme Court justice seat. We can't forget that, so I don't know how that's --

utterances.speaker: DOMENECH
utterances.sentences: OK. See that's why -- that's why they're doing this. That's why the progressive left is going to continue to find a way to get rid of Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: OK. Ben, Jehmu, I appreciate you coming in.

utterances.speaker: DOMENECH
utterances.sentences: Good to be with you.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Now, could the Trump's become --

utterances.speaker: GREENE
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Ed.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: -- an American political dynasty with Ivanka becoming as the winning ticket in 2024. It is ladies' night, when we come back.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: So, Ivanka Trump commander in chief? Some are pondering that idea tonight after President Trump told the Atlantic, quote, "If she ever wanted to run for president, I think she'd be very, very hard to beat." Adding that his daughter has created millions of jobs. Plus, she's good with numbers. Here now for ladies' night, Nan Hayworth, Deirdre Bolton, and Jessica Tarlov. Good to see you all.

utterances.speaker: NAN HAYWORTH, BOARD MEMBER, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S FORUM
utterances.sentences: Hello.

utterances.speaker: DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Good to be with you.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Nan, are you on board?

utterances.speaker: HAYWORTH
utterances.sentences: Nan, Big fan of Ivanka Trump. I've had a privilege of working with her with on a couple of projects. She is intelligent, she is articulate, she is effective, and she deeply cares. I think she would take on that task and be exceedingly successful.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: I suspect that Jessica has a different idea.

utterances.speaker: JESSICA TARLOV, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Listen, I've got a dad too, he things very highly of me.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: We think highly of you, too.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: No, I appreciate that. I accept all of your votes when I decide to run. The president speaks this way. He loves Ivanka. He thinks very highly of her. I was praising her for criminal justice reform. I thought that was --

utterances.speaker: BOLTON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: -- a great advancement there. I've heard that she is very well- liked. I don't think that she has the policy chops or experience to be jumping into a presidential race in 2024 or 2028, or 20 anything. And I don't think that she is someone who is going to really arouse a lot of support beyond Trumpers.

utterances.speaker: BOLTON
utterances.sentences: But a lot of people say it seems like she doesn't even really -- she's not aiming for that.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOLTON
utterances.sentences: Or at least publicly hasn't said that she is interested in --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Well --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Was more about care who had president -- who had political aspiration.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: In fact, Deirdre, here's what she said in August 2016. We'll get to you, Deirdre, to respond.

utterances.speaker: IVANKA TRUMP, DONALD TRUMP'S DAUGHTER
utterances.sentences: Running for office is not something I want to be doing -- no. No. My father always taught me to never say never. But the last time I said no, but never say never, the headline was Ivanka wants to run for office. So, I'm just going to give you a no.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: So?

utterances.speaker: BOLTON
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's pretty clear. I mean, she was running a successful, you know, jewelry, fashion line.

utterances.speaker: HAYWORTH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLTON
utterances.sentences: I mean, I do -- I will say this, I do empathize and sympathize with anybody in the public eye who is there more or less because of their parents.

utterances.speaker: HAYWORTH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOLTON
utterances.sentences: I mean, her life would have been much easier had she stayed in New York. Whether you love or hate her --

utterances.speaker: HAYWORTH
utterances.sentences: Yes, you're right.

utterances.speaker: BOLTON
utterances.sentences: -- this is an easier gig than where she is sitting.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Well, talk about easier. Chrissy Teigen hammering Ivanka Trump. You've heard the idea that she stood by, she's complicit, all that. Here's Chrissy Teigen.

utterances.speaker: CHRISSY TEIGEN, MODEL
utterances.sentences: It's a painful thing to see such a complete lack of empathy when it comes from people like Ivanka, I will say, that can post all day pictures of her children. There are children out there who do not have that opportunity.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: You're shaking your head.

utterances.speaker: HAYWORTH
utterances.sentences: Well, Chrissy Teigen has the opportunity herself. She lives obviously a very prosperous and sheltered life. In a sense, she has the opportunity to pursue her own charitable and most scenery efforts if she likes to. That has nothing whatsoever to do with Ivanka Trump who is spending her time doing amazing things for America's workers, for America's families, and including criminal justice reform.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Jessica, why is it that some on the left seem to have a special desire to just salvage anything that's Trump family?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Listen --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: The kids, the family, you know, the first lady.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Well, because these aren't just kids. They are advisors to the president. They have formal roles; they are running around the White House. That huge Atlantic piece, talks specifically about how Ivanka is always the one who makes sure to be dropping in. Jared is an advisor himself and the other brothers are supposed be running that business but they are spending a lot of time on the campaign trail and on cable news.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Which is they have a right to do.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: Well, it's not clear actually with nepotism laws actually if there have been violations of divestment with companies and who is profiting off the presidency. But I want to touch on what Chrissy Teigen is talking about and this is a big issue for people. You can tell all the time conservative women never get to be called feminist, what is that about? And being a feminist is about advocating for women. The policies that Ivanka Trump supports do not support women. Raising the minimum wage, for instance, two-thirds of the people in America who are on the minimum wage are women. She's not for raising the federal minimum wage. There are heartbeat -- having a higher salary doesn't help women --

utterances.speaker: HAYWORTH
utterances.sentences: Well, having a salary does. But raising the federal minimum wage is not the way to do that.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Deirdre, let Deirdre in.

utterances.speaker: BOLTON
utterances.sentences: Well, she also did have the double child tax credit, right, as part of the 2017 --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: That help people.

utterances.speaker: HAYWORTH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLTON
utterances.sentences: -- that help in theory women -- hopefully --

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: But she has that 50 million USAID fund --

utterances.speaker: BOLTON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: -- that's going to help 50 million women. So, everybody got a dollar from her plan.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Well, do you know what's going to help a lot of people?

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: And there are no --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: As they head into the weekend, this picture of Adam Schiff.

utterances.speaker: TARLOV
utterances.sentences: If they don't have to see me anymore.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Look at this picture of Adam Schiff who tweeted out about Chrissy Teigen. He said, "I might have to delete this but I just want everyone to see that. It's great for the weekend." That's the Story on this Friday night. On Monday, don't miss Martha and Bret's Town Hall with Sen. Bernie Sanders, 6:30 Eastern. I'll see you again, "Fox and Friends," tomorrow at 6:00 am. Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2019 ASC Services II Media, LLC.
